Assignment 1
  • Play Test
  • Task Management
  • Computer Adaptation
  • Semester Schedule

Play Test

Section Contributors

Sean Harris
Emeth Thompson
Justin Hall

The Star System game allows the players to adequately familiarize themselves with a few different aspects of the game. The most notable of these was the Mission Phase, which is arguably one of the more important phases for the Rebel player (at least early game, when considering the Province/Galaxy renditions). And in the process of learning the Mission Phase, you will inevitably encounter character combat, either against other characters, squads (stacked military units), irate locals, or creatures.

Though not a lot of opportunities were presented for either player to detect one another, there were plenty of searches performed, which were often uneventful. Military action never amounted to much, seeing as how the Rebels had difficulties amassing any kind of power in so few rounds of play, and because only one star system was in use, space combat was not permitted, and the potential for movement was limited.

Outlined below is a step by step play through of all the phases for the Rebels and Imperials first turn; a single game turn.

Rebels Player

  • 1 Operation Phase

  • Movement Segment

    Rebel player starts from space, attempting to land on one of four available Environs. As the rebel spaceship entered the Environ, the Imperial player was able to detect the incoming ship via one of the up PDBs (Detection Table was referenced).

  • Enemy Reaction Segment

    Imperial player was unable to react, because in the Star System game, it is only possible to move from one Environ on a planet to another Environ on the same planet (only one planet in the start system has more than one Environ, which the Rebel player did not occupy).

  • Military Combat Segment

    Rebel player did not have military units present, so this segment was skipped.

  • 2 Search Phase

  • Imperial player attempted to search out and attack detected Rebel characters with military units and Imperial characters independently (Search Table was referenced).

  • 3 Mission Phase

  • Mission Assignment Segment

    Rebel player separated their three characters into two mission groups, acting in the same Environ.

  • Mission Action Segment

    Rebel player attempted to gain a new character and start a Rebel camp. In the process of drawing actions cards, irate locals initiated character combat (Irate Locals Chart & Character Combat Results Table referenced). After dealing with irate locals, the Rebel player successfully started a Rebel camp.

  • Bonus Draw Segment

    Rebel character bonuses allowed the Rebel player to successfully find/gain a new character, by drawing bonus cards.

Imperial Player

  • 4 Operation Phase

  • Movement Segment

    Imperial player moves military and Imperial characters around the star system, making use of their mobile military units and their lone starship respectively.

  • Enemy Reaction Segment

    Segment skipped.

  • Military Combat Segment

    Segment skipped.

  • 5 Search Phase

  • The Rebel player at this point is unable to detect the Imperial characters, and thus is unable to search for them, unless they are stacked with military units (which they were not). Segment skipped.

  • 6 Mission Phase

  • Mission Assignment Segment

    Imperial player separated their two characters into two mission groups, acting in separate Environs.

  • Mission Action Segment

    Imperial player attempted to gain a new character and assassinate a detected Rebel character. In the process, Rebel characters detected, performed a search (Search Table referenced) and ultimately found the Imperial assassin; character vs. character combat was initiated (Character Combat Results Table referenced), and Imperial character died. Remaining Imperial character gained a new ally.

  • Bonus Draw Segment

    There was no need to draw bonus cards. Segment skipped.

By the end of the fourth turn, the Rebel player had been completely eradicated, with all their characters either being killed or captured by the Imperials. Furthermore, only one instance of military combat was initiated when the Rebels were able to convert a militia unit via the Mission Phase; the fight was over before it began.

Task Management

Section Contributors

Justin Hall
Emeth Thompson

Tasks are broken into 3 categories, based on the type of game being played. Each game has a series of tasks, and sub-tasks if they inhereit from a parent. The game types have a numeric label which shows the total number of tasks for a particular game type. Each task is uniquely identified via a numeric badge; the badge keeps a running total of the number of tasks in a particular game.

Subsections with blue backgrounds are not considered tasks, but group similar tasks together.

  • Star System Game 8
  • Province Game 10
  • Galactic Game 12

Combat

  • 1 Character Combat

    Combat between characters.

  • 2 Environ Military Combat

    Plantary combat between militaries.

Movement

  • 3 Interplanetary Movement

    Movement between planets.

  • 4 Planetary Movement

    Movement between enivorns.

Missions

  • 5 Mission Assignment

    Assignment of missions to characters.

  • 6 Mission Actions

    Actions user must take to complete mission.

  • 7 Mission Bonus

    Player receives bonuses that can be applied to active missions.

  • 8 Search

    Searching for enemy units.

Combat

  • 1 Character Combat

    Combat between characters.

  • 2 Environ Military Combat

    Plantary combat between militaries.

  • 3 Space Military Combat

    Space combat between militaries.

Movement

  • 4 Hyperspace Movement

    Movement between star systems.

  • 5 Interplanetary Movement

    Movement between planets.

  • 6 Planetary Movement

    Movement between enivorns.

Missions

  • 7 Mission Assignment

    Assignment of missions to characters.

  • 8 Mission Actions

    Actions user must take to complete mission.

  • 9 Mission Bonus

    Player receives bonuses that can be applied to active missions.

  • 10 Search

    Searching for enemy units.

Combat

  • 1 Character Combat

    Combat between characters.

  • 2 Environ Military Combat

    Plantary combat between militaries.

  • 3 Space Military Combat

    Space combat between militaries.

Movement

  • 4 Hyperspace Movement

    Movement between star systems.

  • 5 Interplanetary Movement

    Movement between planets.

  • 6 Planetary Movement

    Movement between enivorns.

Missions

  • 7 Mission Assignment

    Assignment of missions to characters.

  • 8 Mission Actions

    Actions user must take to complete mission.

  • 9 Mission Bonus

    Player receives bonuses that can be applied to active missions.

  • 10 Search

    Searching for enemy units.

  • 11 Galacatic Drawing

    Each player draws their own galactic card type.

  • 12 Resource Collection

    Imperial collects taxes, both players expend Force Points

Computer Adaptation

Section Contributors

Jeff Crocker
Benjamin Cumber

The goal of the computer adaptation should be to free the players of the tedious mathematics and management while also maintaining the charming aspects as well as the intentional design and function. Below is a list of the components, and their proposed adaptations.

  • Physical Components
  • Gameplay Mechanics

Game Board

  • Environ

    Environ are the smallest unit of the gameboard, and thus present a challenge for adaptation as screen size and resolution is an issue. Should mimic board's display of Environ information. Would be nice to be able to re-skin battle setting to match location.

  • Planets

    Planets also should mimic board design, however there are some places digital adapatation may save us space and thus shrink size of game map. For instance, the loyalty scale takes a lot of space being a physical system, but with the substitution of a color scheme and representing icon could be cut down to one squar. Same can be said for other planet characteristics.

  • Star Systems

    Star Systems will not need to be graphically changed much, only whatever is needed to suit planetary changes.

  • Providences

    Provinces will need to be re-done to allow for a nice jigsaw puzzle size and fit of each individual province. This is because due to screen limitations, players will likely only be able to view one province at a time, and navigate between them from a large galaxy map.

  • Galaxy

    The map of the galaxy will need to be simplified and scaled down to fit, and likely only present pertinent macro information, bringing player's attention to issues and then zooming to smaller scale view to actually do micro management.

Pieces

  • Character Pieces

    Character pieces can be very similar to the table implementation. When viewing the game board you cannot see into the stacks at various planets any details of the individuals, until you pick up the pieces to examine. Mimicing this behavior, we need only to display the quantity and possibly total group strength of the entire stack, and then if player examines, show the exact composition, likely linking to the corresponding cards.

  • Standard Military

    Standard military will be shown in a similar fashion, although not as much detail be to given.

Cards

  • Characters and Ships

    A large part of the game's "charm" which I would like to preserve comes across in these cards. For this reason it should be an aim to provide character portraits, item views, etc for all cards just as is done in the board game. These "cards" will be presented to the player as simply the more detailed view of the pieces on the map.

  • Missions

    Mission related cards on the other hand are not present on the board but rather are resulting information. I picture it being easily adapted as a "news bulletin" of sorts that would pop to the player whenever needed.

  • Galactic Events

    Galactic events may also be a part of this "Galactic News Bulletin" and any effects remaining for the duration of the turn may stay pinned in upper right of the screen with a countdown to expiration along with effect to remind and inform the player.

Combat

Dice rolling for ALL combat will not commense until player dictates, but it will be handled by random generator

  • Character Combat

    Combat between characters can be shown using the detailed "card" like view described previously. Both cards would then participate in combat.

  • Environ Military Combat

    Military battles should be set in appropriate Environ. Would be nice to have some aesthetic battle representation.

  • Space Military Combat

    Space combat would have similar adaptation, just with different background imageand units, but easy to implement.

Movement

  • Hyperspace Movement

    Fancy graphic showing origin and destination must remain on map until hyperspace jump is acknowledged by player. Possibly even special movement routine to make it exciting.

  • Interplanetary Movement

    Movement between planets will be shown by moving unit stacks and leaving trail along path so as to leave more information and context for player.

  • Planetary Movement

    Movement between enivorns might be tricky at the scale of the map to show, so as with other movement there need to be some sort of special icon or maybe news bulletin to alert the player who did not make the move that such a change has happened.

Missions

  • Mission Assignment

    There will be a mission manager window which will be brought up at the proper phases, displaying all active characters, their assigned missions, progress, etc.

  • Mission Actions

    Actions will also be taken at the "mission manager" window.

  • Mission Bonus

    Bonuses that can be applied to active missions will present the mission manager to the user and prompt which assignment to assign the bonus.

Systems

  • Resource Management

    At the proper phase, both players will be given financial reports and prompted as to what policies they would like to put in place for future.

  • Turn 'State'

    Process which lists and indicates current turn, phase, state, etc should be present in corner and generally available for player to reference.

  • Search

    Searching will be a computation phase for the game, no need to present the players with all the failed searches, but rather will prompt a Galactic News Bulletin and consequences will be applied.
